channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: James E. Garvey on Chinese Solutions for America’s Carp Problem
item.description: The American researcher recently visited China to learn from its experience with Asian carp, a fish considered a pest in the United States but considered an important source of food, as well as a cultural symbol, in China.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Nerissa Michaels/Illinois River Biological Station, via Detroit Free Press
item.media:description: Silver carp jumping out of the water after being disturbed by the sound of watercraft on the Illinois River.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Hong Kong’s Pan Democrats Must Accept China’s Constitutional Powers
item.description: The conflict stems from the opposition’s unwillingness to accept the constitutional authority of the People’s Republic.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: By SHIU SIN-POR

item.title: Egypt Cracks Down on New Student Protests, Arresting Scores
item.description: The military-backed government is showing little patience with students protesting the Egypt’s leadership and its efforts to control university campuses.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: British Parliament Recognizes Palestinian State in Symbolic Vote
item.description: The symbolic vote was seen as an indication of how public opinion has shifted since the breakdown of peace talks and the Gaza conflict.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Vatican Signals More Tolerance Toward Gays and Divorce
item.description: In remarkably conciliatory language, a synod of bishops appeared to reflect the more tolerant and inclusive direction Pope Francis has set for the church.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO and LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:description: Pope Francis attended an assembly of 200 bishops convened to discuss family issues on Monday at the Vatican.

item.title: Turkey Says No Deal Yet on U.S. Use of Bases in ISIS Fight
item.description: A day after American officials said Turkey had agreed to allow the use of its air bases for operations against the Islamic State, Turkish officials said talks were still underway.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry with Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu of Turkey last month in Ankara.

item.title: Jean Tirole Wins Nobel in Economics for Work on Regulation
item.description: Mr. Tirole, a French economist, has provided insight into how governments can best tame powerful firms, the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences said.
item.dc:creator: By BINYAMIN APPELBAUM
item.media:credit: Toulouse School of Economics, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Jean Tirole, a professor at the Toulouse School of Economics, won the Nobel in economic science on Monday.

item.title: The Ortolan: A Tiny Bird as a French Cause Célèbre
item.description: Celebrity chefs are waging a campaign to bring the bird, banished from menus since 1999, back to the table, prompting protests to keep it protected.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: Court Sentences 12 to Die for Xinjiang Mayhem
item.description: The sentences appeared to reflect the Chinese government’s determination to quell unrest in the Xinjiang region with severe punishments.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Member of U.S. Military Questioned in Death of Filipino
item.description: The Philippine and American authorities are investigating whether a member of the United States military killed a 26-year-old Filipino.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: Taliban Ambush Afghan Security Forces, Killing 14
item.description: The attack is part of a violent campaign that has taken a serious toll on soldiers and police officers across Afghanistan in recent months.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: Car Bomb Kills at Least 15 in Somalia
item.description: A car with explosives was detonated near a popular cafe in Mogadishu in what the government says was an act of terrorism by the Shabab militant group.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM
item.media:credit: Abdulfitah Hashi Nor/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Somali soldier looked at the body of a civilian killed by a suicide car bomb in Mogadishu on Sunday night.

item.title: Bishops Signal Tolerance Toward Gays and Divorce
item.description: In remarkably conciliatory language, a synod of bishops appeared to reflect the more tolerant and inclusive direction Pope Francis has set for the church.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Pope Francis attended an assembly of 200 bishops convened to discuss family issues on Monday at the Vatican.

item.title: Car Bomb Kills 13 in Somalia
item.description: A car with explosives was detonated near a popular cafe in Mogadishu in what the government says was an act of terrorism by the Shabab militant group.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM

item.title: Hungary’s Premier Tightens Hold on Power After Elections
item.description: The conservative prime minister’s party won control of all county assemblies and all but one of the largest cities, including the capital.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary after voting in municipal elections on Sunday in Budapest.

item.title: Building a Bamboo Bulwark Against the Hong Kong Police
item.description: Pro-democracy demonstrators fall back on a favorite building practice in the city to protect themselves against the police.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Pro-democracy protesters built a barricade with bamboo near the government headquarters in Hong Kong on Monday.

item.title: W.H.O. Chief Calls Ebola Outbreak a ‘Crisis for International Peace’
item.description: The virus’s spread in West Africa is “unquestionably the most severe acute public health emergency in modern times,” said Dr. Margaret Chan, the body’s director general.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Hundreds Try to Tear Down Sit-In Barricades in Central Hong Kong
item.description: The police struggled to keep opponents of the pro-democracy campaign at bay, but warned that they, too, were determined to clear the roadblocks.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: A counterdemonstrator tries to remove road blocks set up by pro-democracy protesters in the Central district of Hong Kong on Monday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Relatives of People Detained for Supporting Hong Kong Protests Appeal for Their Freedom
item.description: The relatives of the detainees have spoken out via social media, saying the charges are unjust and “a big insult to the families.”
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The artist Zhui Hun symbolically "’hanged"“ himself from a Communist Party flag during an event in Beijing. He is now being detained.

item.title: As Israeli Police Lock Al Aksa Mosque, U.N. Chief Denounces ‘Provocations’
item.description: Officers entered the compound and found “petrol bombs, stones, bottle rockets and fireworks” as well as “masked Palestinians,” a police spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Big Lie Behind Japanese Whaling
item.description: Tokyo's controversial whaling program isn't really about whales. It's about fish.
item.dc:creator: By PETER WYNN KIRBY

item.title: Sierra Leone’s Soccer Team Struggles With Stigma Over Ebola Outbreak
item.description: The country’s national team has endured a string of indignities since the outbreak of Ebola in West Africa in May.
item.dc:creator: By JERÉ LONGMAN
item.media:description: Sierra Leone's national team at a training session in Abidjan, Ivory Coast. The players continue to face reminders of the Ebola crisis.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Glory to the 'Russian World'
item.description: Putin and his inner circle spin a kind of retrograde, 19th-century nationalism in a desperate effort to preserve power.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL KHODARKOVSKY

item.title: North Korea Says Remains of U.S. Soldiers at Risk of Disappearing
item.description: The remains of thousands of American soldiers killed in the Korean War are being moved from their burial sites because of construction work, state news media said.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: At Oscar Pistorius’s Sentencing Hearing, Descriptions of a ‘Broken Man’
item.description: A witness for the defense team said the punishment should be limited to house arrest and community service, penalties described by the prosecution as “shockingly inappropriate.”
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius, who was found guilty last month of killing his girlfriend, returns to court on Monday for a sentencing hearing.
